title: Suspicious Invoice
narrative: Email from 'acc0unts-pay.co' with urgent invoice and ZIP attachment.

choices.label: Report as phishing; do not open; alert security.
Open the ZIP to verify.
Reply asking for bank details.
Forward to a colleague.

feedback_why: Suspicious domain and ZIP indicate phishing. Opening risks malware.
pro_tip: Verify via known channels; never open unknown attachments.

title: Password Reset Choice
narrative: Choose a new password: 'Summer2025!' or a long unique passphrase in a manager.

choices.label: Use a long passphrase in a password manager.
Use Summer2025!
Re-use old strong password

feedback_why: Passphrases are stronger and easier to remember when unique.

title: Dev Server on Café Wi‑Fi
narrative: Local app listens on 0.0.0.0:5000; a friend can access it on café Wi‑Fi.

choices.label: Bind to 127.0.0.1 or stop; use VPN/bastion if needed.
Leave it; it's a dev box.
Ask café to block port.

feedback_why: Binding to all interfaces exposes service.

title: USB Drop in Car Park
narrative: You find a USB labeled 'Payroll Q3' near the door.

choices.label: Do not plug in; hand to security/IT for analysis.
Check it on a spare PC.
Take home and check later.

hint: USBs can deliver malware via autorun/exploits.
feedback_why: Unknown media is a common infection vector.

title: Tailgating at Entrance
narrative: A stranger follows you into a badge-access area carrying boxes.

choices.label: Politely stop them and ask to badge in separately.
Hold door—looks busy.
Assume they're staff.

title: Vishing for OTP
narrative: 'IT support' calls asking for your MFA one-time code to fix your account.

choices.label: Refuse; report the call; verify via official channel.
Provide code quickly to restore access.
Ask them to email and then send the code.

feedback_why: MFA codes are secrets; sharing defeats protection.
pro_tip: Call back using known helpdesk number.

title: Outdated Software Before Travel
narrative: You're about to travel; updates pending. You consider postponing for a week.

choices.label: Update now and reboot; plan buffer time.
Delay for a week.
Disable updates until return.

title: MFA Fatigue at 11pm
narrative: You receive repeated MFA prompts late at night you didn't initiate.

choices.label: Deny; change password; report to security.
Approve to stop popups.
Ignore and sleep.

hint: Repeated prompts often mean account attack.

title: Captive Portal Wants Corporate Creds
narrative: Hotel Wi‑Fi captive portal requests your corporate username/password.

choices.label: Do not enter; use guest access/VPN; report.
Enter creds—likely required.
Try once to see if it works.

hint: Captive portals shouldn't ask for corporate creds.

title: Upload Customer CSV to Unapproved Cloud
narrative: A partner asks you to upload customer CSV to their personal Dropbox.

choices.label: Decline; use approved secure transfer channel.
Do it quickly; data is needed.
Split into parts to reduce risk.

title: RDP Exposed at Home Lab
narrative: Your home router forwards 3389 to a lab PC for convenience.

choices.label: Close port; use VPN/bastion; enable MFA.
Keep open with NLA only.
It's fine; not work.

title: Hardcoded API Key
narrative: You notice an API key committed to a public repo.

choices.label: Rotate key; remove from history; add secrets scanning.
Delete file and force push.
Keep; unlikely to be found.

hint: Assume secret is compromised once committed.

title: Sharing Screenshots with PII
narrative: You paste a screenshot to chat that includes customer email/phone.

choices.label: Redact or mask PII before sharing.
Share as-is within team.
Delete after sending.

title: Laptop Left in Taxi
narrative: You realise your work laptop might be left in a taxi.

choices.label: Report immediately; remote lock/wipe; change passwords.
Wait to see if driver returns it.
Only report if confirmed lost.

title: QR Sticker on Menu
narrative: A QR sticker is placed over a restaurant's menu QR.

choices.label: Avoid scanning; use official menu or verify URL.
Scan; it's a menu.
Scan but don't click anything.

title: CFO Gift Card Request
narrative: Message from 'CFO' on chat asks for urgent gift cards; says they're in a meeting.

choices.label: Verify out-of-band; report impersonation; do not buy.
Buy cards; send codes quickly.
Ask for reimbursement first.

hint: Gift card scams use urgency + authority.

title: Unapproved Browser Extension
narrative: A colleague asks you to install a 'time saver' Chrome extension that isn't on the approved list.

choices.label: Decline; request it through approval; offer alternatives.
Install—it only needs basic permissions.
Install in a separate profile.

hint: Shadow IT can exfiltrate data via extensions.
feedback_why: Unvetted extensions can read and send data from pages you visit.
pro_tip: Use only approved extensions via the admin catalog.

title: Shoulder Surfing at Café
narrative: You're working on customer data at a café; the table behind you has a clear view.

choices.label: Reposition screen / use privacy filter; avoid PII in public.
Continue; no names visible.
Move to corner but keep screen open.

feedback_why: Public spaces increase risk of data exposure.
pro_tip: Use privacy filters and avoid PII in public places.

title: AI Prompt Injection
narrative: A webpage includes 'ignore previous instructions' text that your internal assistant might process when copying content.

choices.label: Treat page content as untrusted; sanitize before feeding tools.
Paste everything; the assistant is safe.
Disable the assistant entirely.

feedback_why: Prompt injection can cause data exfiltration or unsafe actions.
pro_tip: Sanitize inputs and restrict tools / data access.

title: BYOD No Screen Lock
narrative: A teammate uses personal phone for email without a screen lock.

choices.label: Enforce device policy: PIN/biometrics + remote wipe.
Allow if they don't lose it.
Suggest longer email password instead.

hint: Device lock is first line of defense.
pro_tip: Require MDM and screen lock for BYOD.

title: Push to Prod without Review
narrative: Hotfix is urgent. A senior says to push straight to prod and review later.

choices.label: Require minimal peer review/approval; use feature flags/rollback.
Push now; test in prod.
Delay for a week until full review.

hint: Fast ≠ unreviewed. Use light but real checks.
pro_tip: Keep change windows, approvals, and rollback plans.

title: Split Tunneling Debate
narrative: To improve call quality, someone proposes split tunneling corporate VPN.

choices.label: Allow only for non-sensitive traffic with policy/monitoring.
Disable VPN entirely during calls.
Allow split for everything to speed things up.

hint: Risk-based allowances can work with controls.
pro_tip: Use app-based split with strict rules and monitoring.
